flow.descriptionCdata:
e9c5f3f4-9a3b-41af-a064-4dbc6f2956b1.2780716a-61d7-4804-b47e-a11413dabf8e.callout=Check Inputs\: -Inputs\: vCenterIP,diskDsName,freeSize,interval,retry -Results\: hideReturn(errorCode,errorComponent) e9c5f3f4-9a3b-41af-a064-4dbc6f2956b1.49af0afc-54bd-43bc-923e-dc2c39b26148.description=
Searches for VMWare objects containing a given name (ignoring case). Retrieves each object one at a time from an initial search query as the one used for the SQL Query operation.

Inputs\:
    host - VMWare host hostname or IP.
    user - VMWare username.
    password - VMWare user's password.
    port - Port to connect on.
    protocol - Connection protocol.
Valid values\: "https", "http"
    closeSession - Close the internally kept VMware Infrastructure API session at completion of operation.
Valid values\: "true", "false"
    propsType - VMWare properties type to filter on. Type of object results desired.
Example\: VirtualMachine, Network, ComputeResource, ClusterComputeResource, ResourcePool, HostSystem, Datastore, Datacenter, VirtualApp
    nameToMatch - The string to perform a case insensitive contains match to.  Only objects that contain this string in their name will be matched.  If not specified, all objects of the specified type will be matched.

Responses\:
    success - The operation completed successfully and there are more results available.
    failure - Something went wrong.
    no more - There are no more results to retrieve.

Returns\:
    numberOfResults - Number of results from the query remaining to be retrieved.
    returnResult - Query result item or operation result.
e9c5f3f4-9a3b-41af-a064-4dbc6f2956b1.84ead256-5223-4732-b468-819e21785764.callout=Return error info\: -Inputs\: errorCode,errorComponent -Resupts(Flow OutPut) errorCode,errorComponent e9c5f3f4-9a3b-41af-a064-4dbc6f2956b1.93cff419-493d-406a-b193-ce61b836fff6.description=
Accepts an object in the JavaScript Object Notation format (JSON) and and
creates and populates a flow variable for each member in the object.

The JSON format encodes objects as a set of unordered key/value pairs, which is
similar to a structure or map in other programming languages.  For example,
   { "city" \: "Palo Alto", 
     "state" \: "CA" }
is an object with two elements one with the name "city" having the value "Palo
Alto", and the other being the name "state" with the value "CA".  This operation
would create the flow variables city and state with the values "Palo Alto" and
"CA".

A optional prefix string can be specified that will be prepended to each flow
variable that is created.  For example, if the prefix is set to "my.", then
then the above object would result in the variables my.city (with value "Palo
Alto") and my.state (with value "CA").  This can be useful if flow variables
already exist with the given names to avoid overwriting their values.

JavaScript objects are useful for representing structured data, and are
especially when used within an array.  For example, an operation that retrieves
a set of incidents from an external system may return the entire list in one
array of incident objects.  The description of the enclosing folder,
/Library/Utility Operations/Container/JavaScript Objects has more examples, and
the JSON format is described completely at http\://www.json.org.

Inputs

   object
      The JavaScript object that will be converted into flow variables.  The
      operation will return a failure if the it is not a JavaScript object.
     i.e. \= { "city" \: "Palo Alto", "state" \: "CA","empty"\:"","noValue"\:"${noValue}" }
  
   list
     Check Variables list.  
    The operation will return a failure if the variable value is null in variable list.
     i.e. \=  city,empty,noValue
  delimiter
    The delimiter use on list. default is comma.
    i.e. \= ,
   prefix
      The prefix to prepend to each flow variable name that will be created.
      This is useful for creating unique variable names.

Responses

   success
      The flow variables were successfully created from the object.

   failure
      There was some error in processing the object, most likely because the
      object is not in valid JavaScript Object Notation.  You may wish to use a
      tool such as http\://www.jsonlint.com/ to help diagnose problems with
      JavaScript Object Notation.

Outputs

   A separate output will be created for each member of the object.  Each of
   these outputs may in turn contain another object or array.
e9c5f3f4-9a3b-41af-a064-4dbc6f2956b1.a79c4892-29cd-43c6-8320-df96409e36a6.description=
Search for VMWare objects of type propsType and their properties (propsPathset) from a root object (if any) specified by propsRootObjType and propsRootObj. Retrieve each object's properties one at a time from an initial search query ala SQL Query operation. Please see VMWare Integration Guide for more details.

Inputs\:
host - VMWare host hostname or IP.
user - VMWare username.
password - VMWare user's password.
port - Port to connect on.
protocol - Connection protocol (http or https).
closeSession - Close the internally kept VMWare Infrastructure API session at completion of operation (true, false).
propsType - VMWare properties type (Task, Datacenter, VirtualMachine, Network etc.) to filter on. Type of object results desired.
propsPathset - Property filter's pathset, comma-delimited (eg. name, info.name, runtime.host).
propsRootObjType - The type of the Managed Object Reference (such as VirtualMachine, HostSystem, ComputeResource, ResourcePool, Alarm, Datacenter, Datastore) to begin the search on. Leaving this blank will default the root object to the root folder of the ESX or VC host. 
propsRootObj - The value of the reference (such as vm-123, datastore-123, network-123) used as a root object. Leaving this blank will default the root object to be the root folder of the ESX or VC host. 

Responses\:
success - The operation completed successfully.
failure - Something went wrong. See returnResult for details.
no more - There are no more results to retrieve.

Returns\:
numberOfResults - Number of results from the query remaining to be retrieved.
returnResult - Query result item or reason for failure.
e9c5f3f4-9a3b-41af-a064-4dbc6f2956b1.a79c4892-29cd-43c6-8320-df96409e36a6.prompt=name,summary.capacity,summary.url,summary.freeSpace,vm datastore-3535 e9c5f3f4-9a3b-41af-a064-4dbc6f2956b1.acac4457-126c-4ae8-b996-408965164785.callout=3.18.4.16 Get DataStore Free Space This subflow retrieves free space on a given VM Data Store. If free space is less then provided size then returns error e9c5f3f4-9a3b-41af-a064-4dbc6f2956b1.c93844b9-861b-4712-b72a-a0c7750bc0ab.callout=\ (Nucleus_automation_design_specification_v41\:) 3.18.4.16 Get DataStore Free Space e9c5f3f4-9a3b-41af-a064-4dbc6f2956b1.cedd31fb-b8d6-499d-bc6c-1f90bb539a1e.description=
This operation running scriptlet from Inputs, It can be used to script flow.
attention that do'not used Scriptlet tab, it need empty can be running script from Inputs script. 
This operation does not do anything. It can be used to filter flow variables by defining them as inputs and filtering them in the Results tab.

Inputs\:
    Scriptlet - write on javascript.

Results\:
    returnResult - This is the primary output.
    default this operation return errorCode and errorComponent that donot need add errorCode and errorComponent
    if you want add errorCode and errorComponent used below scriptlet, please refer Outputs sample
       errorCode  from returnResult scriptlet\:    scriptletResult \= scriptletContext.get("errorCode"); 
       errorComponent   from returnResult scriptlet\:   scriptletResult \= scriptletContext.get("errorComponent");
Responses\:
    success - The operation completed as stated in the description.
    failure   -  The operation failure as stated in the description.
    other -  The operation other as stated in the description.
Examples of usage \:

// This template shows how to access operation return data, inputs and context data 
// and how to set context data, responses and results. 

//convert to JSON object
jsObject \= JSON.parse({"var1"\:"value1"}); 
myValue \= jsonOBJ["var1"];

// To access an input simply refer to the input name from the Inputs panel.  For example\: 
myData \= inputName; 
 
// To get value associated with the context key myContextKey\: 
myContextData \= get("myContextKey"); 
 
// To get value associated with the context key myContextKey from the local context\: 
myContextData \= let("myContextKey"); 
 
// To access the return code from a command line or script (note it is a string and must 
// be converted into an integer for numeric processing)\: 
code \=getcode();
 
// To access the output from the operation (for example stdout)\: 
data \= getoutput() 
 
// To access the error string from the operation (for example stderr)\: 
error \=geterror();
 
// Other operations may have different result variables available.  To see the list for 
// a particular operation open the "Result from Field" dropdown on the Outputs tab 
 
// To set the response of the operation (must match one of the responses from the Responses tab)\: 
did(true); // did("success")
did(false); // did("failure")
did("other");
 
// To set the result of the operation 
print( "Your Result Here"); 
println( "Your Result Here"); 
// Use the context to hold data for use by other steps.  It is also helpful to place information 
// into the context to examine variables when developing and debugging scriptlets. 
// For example to place the OutputString information into a context key called 'Output'\: 
putglobal("Output", data); 
 
// Note that the Key and Value are both strings.  For example to place 'code' into the context\: 
putglobal("Code", code.toString()); 
 
// You can also place data into the local context, which means it will only be available to 
// the current flow, but not to its parent flow or other subflows.  To do this\: 
put("LocalVariable","LocalValue"); 

// You can use error function to throw eror message.
error("throw error message");
 
// sleep flow
sleep(interval)
e9c5f3f4-9a3b-41af-a064-4dbc6f2956b1.d7a574ed-c40f-4aa6-a80b-5f5be1b76563.callout=Write Log\: -Inputs\: diskSize freeSpace Scriptlet -Results\: hideReturn(errorCode,errorComponent) e9c5f3f4-9a3b-41af-a064-4dbc6f2956b1.daae859c-ec29-496e-8cbe-42a42c7b306b.description=

e9c5f3f4-9a3b-41af-a064-4dbc6f2956b1.f99718fc-95f2-4286-bf37-e795ebb92947.callout=Run PoserCli\: -Inputs\: nameToMatch, Scriptlet -Results\: hideReturn(propsRootObj errorCode,errorComponent) e9c5f3f4-9a3b-41af-a064-4dbc6f2956b1.fec54db0-4b1b-49a0-a3cb-d0dcccea6418.callout=Run PoserCli\: -Inputs\: propsRootObj, Scriptlet -Results\: hideReturn(freeSpace, errorCode,errorComponent)
flow.name: Get CMO DataStore Free Space

scriptlet.name: Operation Get CMO DataStore Free Space (e9c5f3f4-9a3b-41af-a064-4dbc6f2956b1)
Step Check null List from Inputs in Flow Get CMO DataStore Free Space (93cff419-493d-406a-b193-ce61b836fff6)

step.name: If Flex Disk Down not possible

scriptlet.name: Step If Flex Disk Down not possible in Flow Get CMO DataStore Free Space (cedd31fb-b8d6-499d-bc6c-1f90bb539a1e)
Step Get Datastore Properties by Cluster in Flow Get CMO DataStore Free Space (a79c4892-29cd-43c6-8320-df96409e36a6)
Step Simple Search in Flow Get CMO DataStore Free Space (49af0afc-54bd-43bc-923e-dc2c39b26148)
